verses.text: And now, brothers, we want you to know about the grace that God has given the Macedonian churches.
Out of the most severe trial, their overflowing joy and their extreme poverty welled up in rich generosity.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8–9
rsbNotes.text: 8:1–9:15 This section concerns the collection of money for poor Christians in Jerusalem (cf. Acts 19:21, 22; Rom. 15:25–28; 1 Cor. 16:1–4).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:1
rsbNotes.text:
8:1 grace. Giving money to help other Christians in need was itself the result of God’s grace. He provided both the resources and the willingness to use them.

churches of Macedonia. Philippi, Thessalonica, Berea.

verses.text: For I testify that they gave as much as they were able, and even beyond their ability. Entirely on their own,
they urgently pleaded with us for the privilege of sharing in this service to the saints.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:3
rsbNotes.text: 8:3 Paul tells the comparatively wealthy Corinthian church about the generosity of the impoverished churches in Macedonia, to the north.

verses.text: And they did not do as we expected, but they gave themselves first to the Lord and then to us in keeping with God's will.
So we urged Titus, since he had earlier made a beginning, to bring also to completion this act of grace on your part.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:5
rsbNotes.text:
8:5 not as we expected. They did much more than he expected.

gave themselves. They rededicated their lives to service for the Lord, and then to Paul as His servant.

verses.text: But just as you excel in everything--in faith, in speech, in knowledge, in complete earnestness and in your love for us--see that you also excel in this grace of giving.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:7
rsbNotes.text: 8:7 you excel in everything. Despite its troubles, Corinth was a strong church in many ways. They had many spiritual gifts (1 Cor. 12–14), several of them listed here.

verses.text: I am not commanding you, but I want to test the sincerity of your love by comparing it with the earnestness of others.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:8
rsbNotes.text: 8:8 not as a command. Paul wants giving to be voluntary. In general, though Paul had great authority, he preferred to ask rather than command (Philem. 14 and note), a good pattern for those in authority (Matt. 20:25, 26).

verses.text: For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became poor, so that you through his poverty might become rich.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:9
rsbNotes.text:
8:9 though he was rich. In the glory and honor that was eternally His in heaven.

he became poor. He gave up His heavenly glory and came to earth to live as a man and to suffer and die. The Corinthians, like Christ, should give of themselves for the sake of others. See “The Humble Obedience of Christ” at John 5:19.

verses.text: And here is my advice about what is best for you in this matter: Last year you were the first not only to give but also to have the desire to do so.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:10
rsbNotes.text: 8:10 They had begun to give in accordance with Paul’s instructions in 1 Cor. 16:1–3.

verses.text: Now finish the work, so that your eager willingness to do it may be matched by your completion of it, according to your means.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:11
rsbNotes.text: 8:11 As in all of the Christian life, so it is in giving. Good motives are not enough, but must lead to good actions in accordance with our abilities.

verses.text: For if the willingness is there, the gift is acceptable according to what one has, not according to what he does not have.
Our desire is not that others might be relieved while you are hard pressed, but that there might be equality.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:12
rsbNotes.text:
8:12 As the widow’s offering in Mark 12:41–44 teaches, willingness to give generously is pleasing to God, even though the gift may have to be small because the giver is poor.

not according to what he does not have. This is a warning against giving or promising to give an amount that you really do not have, hoping that God will repay it. Doing this forces a test on God (Luke 4:12). People should give as God causes them to prosper (1 Cor. 16:2). Even so, the more common offense is failing to give immediately and generously when God brings additional income.

verses.text: At the present time your plenty will supply what they need, so that in turn their plenty will supply what you need. Then there will be equality,

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:14
rsbNotes.text: 8:14 fairness. Not that Paul wanted all Christians to have equal possessions or equal income, but that there might be a fair distribution of burdens. Paul calls for equity rather than strict equality.

verses.text: as it is written: "He who gathered much did not have too much, and he who gathered little did not have too little."

rsbNotes.title: 2 Cor 8:15
rsbNotes.text: 8:15 When the people gathered manna in the wilderness, those who gathered more shared with those who had less, and here with respect to money, the rich should share with those in need.
